newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 15.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 15.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Friday.

- Ireland's minister for justice, Nora Owen, has said she does not believe she will have to resign if any of the prisoners released and re-arrested as a result of a legal blunder are freed by the courts next week.

- British sources on Thursday appeared encouraged by a speech by leading Sinn Finn member, Martin McGuinness, and his references to "an indicative time-frame" for the talks process and to John Hume and Gerry Adams's identification of "the means by which this conflict could be permanently ended."
- The Irish police force could receive up to three million Irish pounds worth of free telecommunications services annually by leasing its masts to the private mobile telephone company Esat Digifone.
- Sterling has surged again on international currency markets, driven higher by speculation of further increases in British interest rates.
- An inquiry launced into the remuneration of semi-state chief executives has found that five cases clearly breached Irish government guidelines, it has emerged.
- A government U-turn on plans for an independent prisons authority was revealed on Thursday.
- Angry employers hit out on Thursday at proposed new European legislation which says their staff cannot be compelled to work more than 48 hours in a week.
- The state agencies which provide support to small businesses should be abolished and replaced by one new body, a report published on Thursday by a government committee has recommended.
- The former Phoenix Park racecourse site has been sold in a deal worth 13.5 million Irish pounds.
